text:
<@U2QHEEGBX> I'm not sure whether `.equals` asks for a managed object or not, so that might cause a problem. But also not:
> The only rule to using Realm across threads is to remember that Realm, RealmObject or RealmResults instances cannot be passed across threads. However, you can use an asynchronous query or asynchronous transaction, to offload the operation to a background thread and bring any results back to the original thread for you.
<@U2QHEEGBX> unclosed Realm instances can cause trouble
But I still wonder sometimes about closing them
I just did like this instead
your code does not close your Realm instance
<@U39P7U6EP> ya, I was wondering that
but opens one
The problem with async ones is you can't close it while it's still running, right?
well, if you close the async realm then you won't get the callback
although to be fair, this *would* work but he should also specify an `OnError` callback that also closes the Realm to be sure.
But I'm closing it in onSuccess?
In Kotlin I use `Realm.getDefaultInstance().use {... }`
Yea

Well

as i said

this means Realm is your data layer
I guess
anyhowwwwwwwww
nothing wrong with that
I like Realm
> Simple threading: Objects returned by ObjectBox work in all threads with no strings attached.
well of course
So far I like it because it's simple
because they don't have an active record pattern
and no lazy evaluation
Threading in Realm is like NPE problems in Java
It's a fucking pain in the ass
no
it's a pain in the ass only if you have zero clue what you are doing
threading in Realm is easy
Yes
Same for NPE
You have to play safe
And stuff is messy because of it
not exactly. Sometimes the weirdest things turn out to be null.
no, Realm's threading is messy only if you are doing it wrong
I disagree
you just need to listen on the UI thread
and you need to write on the background thread
very simple
everything else is automatic
That's what everyone is doing most probably
no they are not
that is why they think threading in Realm is hard
But it's a pain to do queries again because it's on a different thread
It's another thing I need to think about
....i've never had a problem with that
It's imo like saying you never had a problem with NPE
worst thing that ever happened was that i had to call `final long id = realmObject.getId()` before calling something
Why should you worry about it when you shouldn't have to?
in which case i was like
"doh i should have done that in the first place"
The managed objects and unmanaged objects are also a pain
not really, you typically don't need unmanaged objects at all
unless you are batch inserting
or want to modify elements on the UI thread in a form or something
these are the only two use-cases
You do need it quite a bit
I'm not on my laptop so I can't give any examples really
i've written 3 applications with realm, I only ever needed unmanaged objects for batch inserts
(which only works if they don't have relations, but that's another thing)
so I seriously doubt there is any *good* example for when you actually need an unmanaged object beyond databinding to it or batch insert
Well if *you’ve* never needed them then they mustn’t be needed!
:stuck_out_tongue:

server returns
you modify the realmobject on background thread and commit
UI automatically shows new state
sure, it's not "clean architecture", but it certainly makes development about 4x faster

Hey there everyone, I have seen the term ___Interaction used for a class and am not sure of what the actual use of these types of classes is. Can anyone direct me to a good read or explain it themselves?
InteractION or InteractOR?
Honestly, not quite sure
just making sure, because they are very different but sound similar :stuck_out_tongue:
I've also seen ViewIntention lately which looks similar

Interaction I have no idea, but interactor would most likely be referring to the Clean arch pattern, where you have Interactor classes that handle fetching data and sending it to presenters

<http://fernandocejas.com/2014/09/03/architecting-android-the-clean-way/>
There we go, that's exactly what I was looking for!
:partyparrot:

<@U3PQZMSF6|iancowley> uploaded a file: <https://androidchat.slack.com/files/iancowley/F3WS1GUBD/screen_shot_2017-01-26_at_10.35.13_am.png|Screen Shot 2017-01-26 at 10.35.13 AM.png> and commented: So this is where they would live?

text: Exactly.
Now I see UseCase mentioned, is that just the naming convention for the classes that are the Interactors?
They usually mean the same thing.  I think they’re interchangable
Okay thanks guys!
Appreciate it :slightly_smiling_face:
Sorry for more questions, but would a presenter use multiple interactors or would one interactor possibly use multiple repositories?
or neither?
1 interactor for multiple repos
imo
Cool thank you :slightly_smiling_face:
I really only find the interactor pattern useful if you have a reason to have multiple repos, or if the logic for your data fetches is complex.
Right, I am planning on multiple repos to separate out the data
App has a LOT of different data calls
